transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: All right, so in terms of things that are going to cause this tension to build up in your back.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yep.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: What does a typical day look like for you? Like what stresses do you put on your spine?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, I normally work for very long hours every day. So, uh, I'm more likely to be 9-10 hours.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: That's a long time sitting. Do you get a chance to get up and move in that time or are you pretty pressed up on it?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No, not really. The work doesn't really allow me to to walk around. Um, I only get my lunchtime.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Do you have an option to have a standing desk so you can break it up that way or?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Not, not really. I I I haven't tried yet, but yeah, I can definitely try that.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah. Yeah, if your job will allow for that, that um that could be a good way to break it up.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Never thought of it.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah. Uh, and when you're not working, like, are you quite active on on your spare time or do you tend to be sort of getting home and sitting on the couch and sitting in the car on the way and back from work, so it's just more sitting or do you do things when you're not working?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I just kind of lie on my couch because I'm so exhausted from work.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Lying is good in in that there's a different load on your spine, but it sounds like you need more movement in there.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, I think so, but just I'm too tired.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah. Do you have any sports or hobbies or not, not?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Mm, I never do any sports particularly.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: So, um, yeah, nothing really.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: What about on the weekend when you're not so exhausted from work, you go out and go for walks or anything like that?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, I normally just watch TV all the time on on my weekend. Um, no, I don't really have the energy to go out for exercise or anything.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah. This could be part of the problem though. Because when you look at your spine, for example, the discs in here, for them to get nutrients, they need movement.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Oh.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: And if you're talking about the capsule, it's just mostly white fibrous tissue. It gets its nutrients from inside the bone in the vertebrae, you have to get red bone marrow and so forth and some of those nutrients will quickly go into the disc and have to exchange your nutrients because you don't have blood vessels in there. It's requiring loading and unloading, loading and unloading constantly to to keep them healthy.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Same with the joints in here, if it's inflamed, you need movement to dissipate that inflammation, get nutrients to to make its way into maintain the health of that. So that could be partly problem that you're not moving enough.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, okay.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: So if this is really seized up at the moment, you need to get moving. Chiropractic care can be good to loosen it up, but you're also going to need to do some day-to-day movement to to get them to improve, I think.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Okay, I see.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: So if you were to point to where where the pain is.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Mhm.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Where are we talking about? Is it more on the right, more on the left, how low, down the back?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I think it's both left and right and lower down the back.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: So the right sort of runs down into the pelvis in in in here sort of thing?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, that's right.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Okay. Is it um sharp with walking and that sort of thing or standing from sitting, anything particularly that tend to aggravate it?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, I think it's more constant recently and it's it's very sharp. Um, and yeah.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, I don't think movements really affects anything. It's just yeah, that's about it.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yes, aching in the back kind of all the time, is that right? All the time.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: That sounds to me like there's a little bit of inflammation there. So once again, movement can help to just try to help to break that cycle. So it does sound like giving you exercise, I think that's one of the things we we can get to to work.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Unless that gives you sharp pain. But just that aching background pain.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Oh yeah.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Uh, what about sleeping and and postures for that? Is that been aggravated at all?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Uh, I I I don't really notice it when when I'm sleeping. So I think sleeping um, and normally when I just wake up in the morning, it gets better.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: So, um, I think I normally if I had a really good sleep, it doesn't really.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: So it's more towards the end of the day when you've been sitting all day and then once you go down and relax it it sort of stresses it up.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah. That's right. Yeah, that's right.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Often what it is is really inflamed in the pelvis, turning over in bed and that sort of thing can be problematic, but if it doesn't cause that at this stage it's it's more like like a low grade inflammation, not not really as acute at at this point.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: It's just on and off. Sometimes it's bad, sometimes it's all right.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: So in terms of it being on and off, has it been sort of persistent all the time for up to three months or is it only a point in time really?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, no, not to three months. Maybe just longest for one or two weeks.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah, that's good. Yeah, when you have really long periods of pain, it can start to cause changes in your perception of pain to be a little bit more susceptible to feeling it even more. So if if you don't, that won't be the case for you though, so that's actually good.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Okay, great.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Um, right. So does it stop you from doing anything?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Uh, I don't really do anything anyway, so I don't really. But I do feel really painful if I need to stand up for a long time. Say if I need to uh do cleaning or cooking or uh anything that requires me a lot of standing or uh like a lot of bending down. Um, it does really uh worse the pain.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah, bending definitely loads it more. You get a lot of shear force through through those joints.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, that's right.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Um, okay. But I've not nerve pain or sciatic pain like pain radiating down your leg or anything like that?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Not, it doesn't affect my leg yet.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: No. That's good. Yeah. What about the muscles around that region in the hips and that? Do they get aching and tight or not?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, they do. They do get uh sore and ache sometimes. Uh when it's really like typically when I finish work, it gets worse.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: In that area. Yes.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: So what have you tried so far? Is there anything you've tried that sort of worked a bit? Massages or physio or maybe a chiro or?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, I haven't tried anything like really official, but it I just tried some uh you know those um massages from um the the the commercial shops.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, yeah, they uh sometimes they help depending on the massager though.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Uh, but sometimes it doesn't it it makes the pain worse.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Like if they didn't do it properly.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah, that's tricky. Um, yeah. Okay. So you've tried to tried to release the muscle tension, but you haven't tried the chiropractic care, so it's a bit of a different angle obviously to.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, I've never tried that before.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: And in terms of exercises, is there anything you can do at home that relieves the pain? There's stretches or um different hot pack or cold pack or?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, um if if it's really, really bad, I normally put a pain relief patch on the back.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Oh yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Uh, I I think those are available like I got it from the chemist warehouse.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: There's I don't know some medicine on it to help the pain.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah, I'm the pain sort of thing.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Um, cool. And in terms of lifestyle things, obviously you get aching if you sit for long hours, it's hard to avoid because of work.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, that's right.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Um, but I definitely can try more exercising if when off work or at home.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah, that's how I'm working.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah. Yeah, I think that would be a good idea for you. And I can try the standing desk.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah. Yeah, if if your work is open to that, I think that could be a big game changer. I mean, have you just said when you first get into work in the morning, stand for a couple of hours and then after lunch, same thing and.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Just break it up a little bit that way. That's a good idea.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Mhm.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: So obviously your goal is to get rid of this pain to start with. Uh, anything else you want to achieve by coming in here?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Uh, well, that's pretty much the only concern I have. I it just really bothers me in the recent five years.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Um, I don't.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: It's annoying to have chronic pain all the time. Like that's that's what life's supposed to be.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah. That's right. Um, it doesn't have I don't have it before like uh when I was younger, just graduated. It just recently happened in the.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: You're still young, you don't don't want to have chronic aches and pain now. Uh, like imagine 15 years from now sort of thing. Like the earlier you address things like this the better and if you can clear it out, um, it's less likely to come back. The the the longer it's been there and the more ingrained and the more complex it becomes to to resolve. So good on you for for addressing it.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Okay. Yeah, I think that's great.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: All right, so next up, we're going to have a look at your postures because it can give me some ideas about uh where where the load is and and um what your body is trying to to compensate. For example, if you have more inflammation on this side, you might lean over to that side or so forth. So uh yeah, heading to that next and try to figure out what's going on.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Okay, great. Thank you, doctor.

transcript.speaker: Doctor
transcript.text: Thank you.

cause.work: The patient works long hours (9-10 hours) and doesn't have the opportunity to move around much during work.
cause.sports_injuries: The patient does not participate in any sports.
cause.summary: The primary cause appears to be prolonged sitting at work with limited movement, leading to tension and pain in the back. Lack of physical activity outside of work exacerbates the issue.

presentation.main_complaint: The patient's main complaint is back pain.
presentation.onset: The pain has been bothering the patient for the past five years.
presentation.is_chronic: No, the pain is on and off, lasting for one to two weeks at a time.

life_effect.activities_impact: The pain makes it difficult to stand for long periods, clean, cook, or bend down.
life_effect.nerve_root: No, the pain does not radiate down the leg.

intent.previous_care: The patient has tried commercial massages, which sometimes help but can also worsen the pain.
intent.previous_exercises: The patient uses pain relief patches when the pain is really bad.
intent.lifestyle_changes: The patient is considering trying a standing desk and incorporating more exercise into their routine.
intent.why_not_healed: The patient's lack of movement and prolonged sitting at work are likely contributing to the persistent pain.
intent.goal: The patient's primary goal is to get rid of the back pain.

summary.presentation: The patient presents with back pain that has been bothering them for the past five years. The pain is located on both the left and right sides of the lower back and is described as constant and sharp. It is aggravated by prolonged standing and bending down.
summary.life_effect: The pain impacts the patient's ability to perform daily activities such as cleaning, cooking, and standing for extended periods. The patient also experiences soreness and aching in the muscles around the hips.
summary.goal: The patient's main objective is to eliminate the back pain and improve their overall quality of life.
